docs.snippet: When State Representative Hans Dunshee recently proposed changing the name of the Jefferson Davis Highway here, he did not think he would be stirring up a major political controversy.     Truth be told, hardly anybody in Washington State seems to ...
docs.lead_paragraph: When State Representative Hans Dunshee recently proposed changing the name of the Jefferson Davis Highway here, he did not think he would be stirring up a major political controversy. Truth be told, hardly anybody in Washington State seems to have known there even was a Jefferson Davis Memorial Highway here, diagonally across an entire continent from the cradle of the Confederacy.
docs.abstract: Radio talk shows zero in on bill introduced in Washington State Legislature by Rep Hans Dunshee that would rename Jefferson Davis Memorial Highway to honor William P Stewart, black Civil War veteran who fought for Union and settled in Snohomish; Sons of Confederate Veterans and United Daughters of the Confederacy oppose measure; so does Rep Thomas M Mielke, Republican, who says he may still vote for it if Stewart's descendants are on hand for vote; photos (M)

headline.main: Road Named for Jefferson Davis Stirs Spirited Debate

docs.snippet: Iraqi opposition leaders have asked the Bush administration to provide military training to insurgents trying to overthrow Saddam Hussein, the opposition leaders said today.     In meetings with top State and Defense Department officials in the la...
docs.lead_paragraph: Iraqi opposition leaders have asked the Bush administration to provide military training to insurgents trying to overthrow Saddam Hussein, the opposition leaders said today. In meetings with top State and Defense Department officials in the last two days, the Iraqi opposition has renewed its appeal for a program of military training. The idea is to train selected Iraqi opposition commanders in the United States who would in turn provide training to insurgents in Iraq.
docs.abstract: Iraqi opposition leaders say they have asked Bush administration to provide military training to insurgents trying to overthrow Saddam Hussein; say they renewed appeal for program of military training during recent metings with top State and Defense Dept officials; their idea is to train selected Iraqi opposition commanders in US who would in turn provide training to insurgents in Iraq; opposition leaders say they were heartened by Pres Bush's description of Iraq as part of 'axis of evil' in his State of Union address; senior American official says State Dept has not dropped longstanding view that training plan is impractical; American allies are fearful that administration is elevating military options above diplomacy; photo (M)

headline.main: Iraqis Seek to Oust Hussein With U.S. Military Training

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The shutting down of independent TV by the Kremlin (''Silencing Critics of the Kremlin,'' editorial, Jan. 23) follows the tactics of the Peruvian strongman Alberto K. Fujimori.     In 1997, the owner of Frecuencia Latina TV, Baru...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The shutting down of independent TV by the Kremlin (''Silencing Critics of the Kremlin,'' editorial, Jan. 23) follows the tactics of the Peruvian strongman Alberto K. Fujimori. In 1997, the owner of Frecuencia Latina TV, Baruch Ivcher, lost his station and was slapped with an international arrest warrant after broadcasting critical reports about the Peruvian secret service. Similarly, the Russian Federal Security Service -- the real power behind President Vladimir V. Putin -- declared war against NTV and TV-6 for reporting on carnage in Chechnya.
docs.abstract: Badri Patarkatsishvili letter on Jan 23 editorial holds he, Boris A Berezovsky and Vladimir V Gusinsky, owners of independent Russian television networks, face extradition requests on trumped-up charges for reporting on carnage in Chechnya

docs.snippet: A political firestorm has erupted in the Philippines over the impending arrival of some 650 American soldiers dispatched to help battle an Islamic insurgency. A few senators here are even demanding the impeachment of President Gloria Macapagal Arr...
docs.lead_paragraph: A political firestorm has erupted in the Philippines over the impending arrival of some 650 American soldiers dispatched to help battle an Islamic insurgency. A few senators here are even demanding the impeachment of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, only a year into her term, and her vice president has said he feels uneasy about the policy. In an attempt to calm the political furor in a nation that 11 years ago voted to end a century of nearly unbroken American military presence, Philippine and American officials today stressed again and again that Filipinos will do the fighting and Americans will do the advising.
docs.abstract: Political firestorm erupts in Philippines over impending arrival of 650 American soldiers dispatched to help battle Islamic insurgency; there are calls for impeachment of Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo; Vice Pres Teofisto Guingona denies rumors that he will resign as foreign secretary, but he has been publicly unenthusiastic; Philippine and American officials, seeking to calm political furor, stress that Filipinos will do fighting and Americans will do advising; newspapers feature banner headlines quoting Sen Sam Brownback of Kansas referring to Philippines as 'the next Afghanistan'; Bownback was discussing American missionary couple being held hostage by Abu Sayyaf insurgents, who are suspected of having links to Al Qaeda (M)

headline.main: Unease Grows In Philippines On U.S. Forces

docs.snippet: Gen. Van Tien Dung, commander of the Communist offensive that captured Saigon to end the Vietnam War, died on Sunday. He was 84 and had a history of hypertension and heart problems.    Vietnam state television, which announced the death, said Gene...
docs.lead_paragraph: Gen. Van Tien Dung, commander of the Communist offensive that captured Saigon to end the Vietnam War, died on Sunday. He was 84 and had a history of hypertension and heart problems. Vietnam state television, which announced the death, said General Dung would receive a state funeral in Hanoi on Thursday. It called him one of Vietnam's ''talented military commanders and strategists in one of the most glorious moments in our history -- the Great Spring Victory.''
docs.abstract: Gen Van Tien Dung, commander of Communist offensive that captured Saigon to end Vietnam War, dies at 84; his military career reviewed (M)

headline.main: Van Tien Dung, 84, of Vietnam; Led the Final Assault on Saigon

docs.snippet: An article on Feb. 20 about Urs Boegli of the International Committee of the Red Cross, the first human rights official to inspect the conditions under which prisoners from Afghanistan are being held at the United States Naval Base at Guantánamo ...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Feb. 20 about Urs Boegli of the International Committee of the Red Cross, the first human rights official to inspect the conditions under which prisoners from Afghanistan are being held at the United States Naval Base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, referred incorrectly to the precedents for the United States' holding of war captives. The prisoners in Cuba are not the first the United States has detained since World War II. In the Korean War, the United States and South Korea briefly maintained separate prisoner camps before they were consolidated under the United Nations. The Americans did not hand the captured soldiers over to the South Koreans.
docs.abstract: Correction of Feb 20 article about Urs Boegli of International Committee of Red Cross, first human rights official to inspect conditions at Guantanamo Bay prison camp; earlier US detentions there noted

docs.snippet: The residents of the hillside slum of Boa Vista wonder, now that the rebel leader Jonas Savimbi is dead, what is next for their country and what is next for them, the poor and weak in a nation ruled by wealth and war.    A charming statesman and r...
docs.lead_paragraph: The residents of the hillside slum of Boa Vista wonder, now that the rebel leader Jonas Savimbi is dead, what is next for their country and what is next for them, the poor and weak in a nation ruled by wealth and war. A charming statesman and ruthless commander, Mr. Savimbi, who was 67, became the embodiment of a 27-year war that has made Angola one of the most desperate places in the world. It was an image he relished, and until he was killed on Friday by government commandos, it was an image his enemies were happy to burnish, the perfect bogeyman for the profound problems of this country.
docs.abstract: Angola, which is rich in natural resources, is rife with disease, malnutrition and violence of war; Jonas Savimbi, who became embodiment of 27-year civil war that made Angola one of most desperate places in world, is now dead; with him gone, nation's poor and weak wonder what is next for them; Pres Jose Eduardo dos Santos is scheduled to visit Pres Bush at White House this week; photo; map (M)

headline.main: Amid Riches, Angola's Poor Consider Their Future

docs.snippet: The Supreme Court said today that it was upholding a 20-year prison term for Lori Berenson, the New York woman convicted last June of collaborating with a Marxist rebel group in its war against the Peruvian government.    Four of five judges on th...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court said today that it was upholding a 20-year prison term for Lori Berenson, the New York woman convicted last June of collaborating with a Marxist rebel group in its war against the Peruvian government. Four of five judges on the panel voted to affirm the sentence, exhausting Ms. Berenson's legal appeals, the presiding judge, Guillermo Cabala, announced.
docs.abstract: Peru's Supreme Court upholds 20-year prison term for Lori Berenson, American convicted in June 2001 of collaborating with Tupac Amaru Marxist rebel group in its war against Peruvian government; she was arrested in 1995 and sentenced to life in prison by military junta, but sentence was overturned; was retried by new three-judge panel; can seek pardon from Pres Alejandro Toledo (S)

headline.main: Berenson Loses Peruvian Appeal Of Her 20-Year Prison Sentence

docs.snippet: A onetime Soviet army officer accused of illegally ferrying arms to the Taliban and Al Qaeda terrorist network and to combatants in African civil wars appeared abruptly in a Moscow radio studio today, insisting on the air that he was innocent.    ...
docs.lead_paragraph: A onetime Soviet army officer accused of illegally ferrying arms to the Taliban and Al Qaeda terrorist network and to combatants in African civil wars appeared abruptly in a Moscow radio studio today, insisting on the air that he was innocent. In an interview with Vladimir Varfolomeyev of Ekho Moskvy news radio, the former officer, Victor Bout, said that the charges ''resemble more a script for a Hollywood thriller,'' and suggested that they were further evidence of a Western vendetta against Russians.
docs.abstract: Victor Bout, former Soviet army officer, goes on Moscow radio to deny accusations that he illegally ferried arms to Taliban and Al Qaeda terrorist network and to combatants in African civil wars; acknowledges that his air-freight company made regular trips to Afghanistan but refuses to say what cargo his flights carried or to whom they were delivered; United Nations has accused Bout's company of breaking international weapons embargoes; three of his associates are in Belgian prison and at least one is said to be providing evidence against him (M)

headline.main: Russian Goes on the Air To Deny Al Qaeda Ties

docs.snippet: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, today criticized the leftist president of Venezuela, Hugo Chávez, expressing concern about his views on democracy and the war on terrorism.    Secretary...
docs.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, today criticized the leftist president of Venezuela, Hugo Chávez, expressing concern about his views on democracy and the war on terrorism. Secretary Powell made the remarks in response to a question about allegations that Venezuela is supporting leftist guerrillas in neighboring Colombia.
docs.abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell, testifying at Senate hearing, criticizes leftist Venezuelean Pres Hugo Chavez, expressing concern about his views on democracy and war on terrorism, reference to allegations that Venezuela is supporting leftist guerrillas in nieghboring Colombia (S)
